However, I'd like to point out that the probability of two consecutive high-quality products is 25% (50% x 50%), and we've already seen that happen twice in a row. This is a deviation from the expected probability, and it's more likely that the next product will be low-quality to'regress to the mean'. Think of it as a correction to the observed frequency.

I understand your point, but I'm not convinced that the concept of'regression to the mean' applies here. Each product is an independent event, and the probability of a product being high-quality is still 50%. I'll take the product and see what happens!
